title: A two-regime Markov-Switching GARCH trading algorithm for US Leisure & Enterteinment stocks
text:
1 Introduction
This site is for the research documentation published in a private GitHub repository for replication purposes and as supplementary material for the paper A two-regime Markov-switching, new sentiment multinomial algorithm for leisure and entertainment tourism stocks, published in the journal Management decision in the **** special number.
The present site gives a detail of how did the authors collected and processed the input data and gives to the reader the steps and R code used to estimate the Markov-switching model to forecast the probability \(\xi_{s=2,t+1}\) of being in the high volatility regime at \(t+1\). Also details the steps for the following trading rule with these forecasted volatilities:
\[
S_t=\left\{
\begin{array}{l}
\text{Sell if } \xi_{s=2,t} > 0.5 \\
\text{Buy or hold if } \xi_{s=2,t} \leq 0.5
\end{array} \right.
\tag{1.1}\]
The core idea is to estimate the probability \(\xi_{s=2,t+1}\) from a sequential selection of the MS-GARCH models of the following at \(t\)::

A symmetric Student-T log-likelihood function (LLF) with a homogeneous time-fixed volatility.
A symmetric Student-T log-likelihood function (LLF) with a homogeneous symmetric GARCH volatility.
An symmetric Student-T log-likelihood function (LLF) with a homogeneous asymmetric EGARCH volatility.
An asymmetric Student-T log-likelihood function (LLF) with a homogeneous time-fixed volatility.
An asymmetric Student-T log-likelihood function (LLF) with a homogeneous symmetric GARCH volatility.
An asymmetric Student-T log-likelihood function (LLF) with a homogeneous asymmetric EGARCH volatility.

From these models, the authors selected the one with the lowest Akaike (1974) value and use it to estimate the probability \(\xi_{s=2,t+1}\) of being in the high volatility regime at \(t+1\) as follows:
\[
\left[
\begin{array}{l}
\xi_{s=1,t+n}\\
\xi_{s=2,t+n}
\end{array}
\right]=\mathbf{\Pi}^n\left[
\begin{array}{l}
\xi_{s=1,t}\\
\xi_{s=2,t}
\end{array}
\right]
\tag{1.2}\]
Where \(\pi\) is the transition matrix of the Markov-switching model, \(\xi_{s=1,t}\) is the smoothed probability of being in the low volatility regime at \(t\), and \(\xi_{s=2,t}\) is the probability of being in the high volatility regime at \(t\).




Akaike, Hirotugu. 1974. “A New Look at the Statistical Model Identification.” IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control 19 (6): 716–23. https://doi.org/10.1016/J.CUB.2017.09.001.
